dialogues.text: It’s good to be seen. Lauren forces an awkward hug that neither are happy about

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So. What have you been doing lately?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (overselling) I work for Morty Bronstein. His clients have published over 75 literary masterpieces. I’m pretty much his right and left hand. He's retiring soon and I’m going to take over the business. You?  20.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: (lying through her teeth) Well, I’m doing some ground- breaking stuff in advertising. I’ve single-handedly pushed forward a great campaign for a chain of comedy clubs here in Manhattan. Our ads are...all over Times Square. Jesse chokes back a laugh, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Sounds great. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay you two. This is a fantastic place and you’re both insane if you let it go. So, I want you both to close your eyes and imagine: (they reluctantly close them) A big beautiful couch in the corner. Cute frames with nothing inside hanging on the walls. Brunch at a small table by the large windows.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: You just described Monica and Rachel’s apartment.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I love brunch.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Of course you do.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’m not done. This is not an apartment for someone fresh out of college. This is for someone who's got their shit together. Someone who’s making their life happen! This place is for the two of you! Now on the count of three, I want you to both open your eyes and forgive each other for your silly pasts and get ready to step into the future of your incredible apartment. One... Two... Three. The girls open their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: That was so nice, Jesse.  21.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Almost as nice as kicking someone out into a world full of murderers, rapists, and drug dealers.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: When it’s hot outside, my parents say that the car still smells like pee.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I was almost arrested that night for being a prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You peed in my car.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: This isn’t going to work.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: No, clearly it’s not. They angrily part ways. As they head for the door, they overhear JACK, the real estate broker, talking to MARIA, another interested person.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's really a lovely building. Quiet, friendly neighbors, and of course, that key to Gramercy Park. Both Katie and Lauren’s eyes grow wide. They rush over.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Key to Gramercy Park?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: It's so pretty in there! Katie links her arm with Lauren’s.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: We'll take it. Lauren looks at Katie’s linked arm and pulls her aside.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (whispering) What do you think you're doing? I don’t want to live with you!  22.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: (whispering) I don’t want to live with you either! But come on, look at this place. And Gramercy Park?!

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (takes a beat, then) Can you afford half of the rent?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I can make it work. We’ll take turns being in the living room. And you can have all the brunch you want. Lauren looks at Katie. She looks around the place.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (to herself) I should make bold choices. Bold choices. (to Katie) Ohhh man. Okay. Let’s do it. But no Ikea in the living room! They march back over to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE LAUREN
dialogues.text: Sorry lady, but get outta my Where do we sign? apartment! INT. KATIE AND LAUREN’S APARTMENT, KATIE’S BEDROOM- DAY Katie unpacks garbage bags. A pedicure chair sits in the middle of the room. Lauren wiggles a pillow into a shabby chic pillow sham as she leans into Katie’s doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Is that a pedicure chair?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Isn’t it funny?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Funny furniture? Hmm. Keep it in here, please.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Whatever. Nice pillow case. Pottery Barn?  23.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Pillow sham. Anthropologie.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Where yuppy hippies go to die. (beat) So, I was thinking we could divide up the bills. Like you pay them for the first three months, and then I’1ll pay them the next three.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Nice try. But I don’t think so. Who knows, in three months, you could run off and join the circus.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Good one. I was kidding. (beat) What time do you leave for work in the morning? So we can figure out the shower.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Me too. Shit. You can shower anytime before 7:30. Are you going to come into my room all the time?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I was trying to be nice.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Next time, send a fruit basket. Lauren shrugs and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Fine. And don’t forget to bring the least to that place on twenty third tomorrow! INT. MORTY BRONSTEIN’S OFFICE - MORNING Lauren sits in front of Morty in his office. A humidifier runs in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MORTY
dialogues.text: So what’s the occasion?  24.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You just called me in here.

dialogues.speaker: MORTY
dialogues.text: Oh right. You’re so smart. That’s why I hired you. (off Lauren’s smile) And that’s why you’re gonna be great out there on your own. (Lauren's smile falls) I'm tired. I’m old. Let’s face it, I don’t do anything anymore. It’s time to close the old place down.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: But what about your clients? I was thinking that I could--

dialogues.speaker: MORTY
dialogues.text: I took it upon myself to make this easy for you and set them up with fancy young agents.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: And what am I?

dialogues.speaker: MORTY
dialogues.text: You? You’re a secretary.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: But I’ve worked as your assistant for 5 years. I know your business inside and out. I’ve been doing it on my own for the past year at least!

dialogues.speaker: MORTY
dialogues.text: But you’re a woman and women are secretaries, not agents.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: What is this, 1954?

dialogues.speaker: MORTY
dialogues.text: A great year... Look, you make a wonderful coffee, but you’re just lacking something to make you an agent.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: What? What am I lacking?

dialogues.speaker: MORTY
dialogues.text: A penis.  25. Lauren is crushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie steps up to the teenage RECEPTIONIST, who is textin her phone and laughing to herself.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I’m just dropping off the lease for apartment 12-F. In the Gramercy Park building?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. So, I’m such an idiot. I sent over, like, the wrong lease. That one was for 14-F. She pulls out a lease from her drawer. RECEPTIONIST (CONT’D) Can you sign this one for me instead? My dad’s bugging out. Is your roommate here? Katie shakes her head. Clearly she’s alone. RECEPTIONIST (CONT’D) Shoot. (looks around) Um, that’s okay. It’ll be just be under your name then. I mean, it’1l technically be your place, but if that’s okay with you, it’s okay with me. Katie thinks about it for a moment. RECEPTIONIST (CONT’D) You can forge her name on it too, if you want. I don’t care. Katie smiles sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: That's ok. We’re best friends. She won't mind if it’s just my name. Forgery is so wrong.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Great. Katie hands finishes signing the lease and hands it over. walks out triumphantly, giving the girl a pageant queen w  26. INT. KATIE’S APARTMENT KITCHEN - THE NEXT DAY Katie, over-dressed for work in a suit, eats a bowl of fr loops. Lauren emerges from her room, in her pajamas, with empty red wine bottle and puffy eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Do we have recycling yet?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Again with this. Lauren looks less than amused.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a box under the sink, Earth girl. (notices the pajamas) Casual Tuesday at work?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I’m going in an hour late today. Lauren mopes over and tosses the bottle. She looks toward living room and sees the pedicure chair and a stripper po LAUREN (CONT’D) Um. What’s happening in there?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I exercise on the pole. And the chair is for my back. I told you. Lauren collapses at the table.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Whatever. I don’t have the strength.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Your eyes are all puffy. Were you smoking weed this morning?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: No. Gross. Lauren sits at the table. Silence. Then... LAUREN (CONT’D) Have you ever been in love?  27.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Ehh, I can’t be tied down. I don’t have time to waste on personal relationships. Women will stab you in the back, and men only wanna stab you wherever you'll let them - if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Then I doubt you’d understand. I was with Charlie for 3 years! I thought he was my person! same plans, same dreams, same bed. And now he’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Your person? Gross. Jesse told me you might be in denial about your boring relationship.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Whatever. And what do you mean women will stab you in the back?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Women are bitches. Bye woman!

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: To the bathroom. Jeez!

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Why don’t you just pee in this candle-holder? Lauren slumps in her seat. A moment later, Katie emerges heads to the door. I’m going to work. See ya. Wouldn’t wanna be ya. And she’s out the door. Lauren sighs, takes off her blaze heads to the couch and turns on the TV. INT. KATIE AND LAUREN’S APARTMENT-— LAUREN’S ROOM - THAT

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Days of our Lives plays on the TV while Lauren back in he PJ's, sits at her desk looking at her bank account online  28. ANGLE ON THE COMPUTER: Checking 2537: $2047.34. Lauren si and clicks another window to a completed Monster.com job application. She hits submit job and picks up her cell ph

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s Charlie! Leave-- Lauren hangs up. She dials her phone on speaker.

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: INT. LAUREN’S PARENTS LONG ISLAND HOUSE - KITCHEN -

dialogues.speaker: SIMULTANEOUS
dialogues.text: ADELE, 58, and adorable, chops vegetables while SCOTT, 60 with an lovable comb-over, paints a chess set.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (ON THE SPEAKER PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi, mom.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Oh hi, sweetie! Hold on, let me get dad. Adele brings another phone to Scott even though they’re i the same room.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi my sweetie. How’s the new apartment? And your roommate?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Apartment’s great. Roommate’s whatever. But, uhm...Morty’s finally retiring.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT ADELE
dialogues.text: That’s my girl! And you're finally taking over! This is great! LAUREN (CONT’D) Uh, no. He’s just retiring. I’m not taking over. scott But what about our plan?  29.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, since I’m a girl, and Morty’s a sexist old-man, there is no more plan.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Mom, I wasted 5 years of my life giving insulin shots to someone that thinks because I have a vagina, I’m incapable of doing more than looking pretty. It’s over and I don’t want to talk about it anymore. Silence. Adele stops chopping.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Honey, nice girls don’t say vagina. scott (chipper) Well, okay. This is no big deal. You're smart, you’re professional--

dialogues.speaker: ADELE

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I've already applied at Random House. And I’m doing Penguin and St. Martins tomorrow. The big ones. I'd really like to start doing something more fulfilling.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: No, no. Thank you, but I want to do this on my own, okay? ScoTT Okay, that’s fine. Do you need money? What about rent in that new apartment? What do you need?  30.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You guys are the best, but I have a little in savings for rent this month. And I know I’1l get a job soon. Thank you, but no thank you. I'm 28, I just can’t have you guys helping me out anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Well you can always move back in with us. Lauren smiles and nods un-easily. That’s the last thing s wants to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lauren, wearing a proper shirt and her pajama pants, figh her way through times square while drowning her sorrows i extra large bag of chocolate covered popcorn. Some of it’ her face. Meanwhile, only a few feet away is Katie. Her power blaze now wrapped around her waist. She hands a YOUNG MAN a fli

dialogues.text: Hey, you like comedy? (off the man’s confused look) English? (more confusion) No? Great. She hands him the flier and then pushes her way through t crowd. She doesn’t know it’s her, but she taps Lauren on shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, pajamas, you like comedy? Lauren turns around and sees that it’s Katie. Both of the are shocked.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: KATIE

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (judge-y) I see. Katie registers the pajamas and the fact that it’s mid-da

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN

dialogues.speaker: KATIE LAUREN

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: And this is how Miss productive fills her time?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Yeah, clearly I should take notes from you on how to have a successful career.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me, I have some important work to get done.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Why not save your breath and just wear a sandwich board?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Unemployed. They both turn and huff off in opposite directions.  32.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Madison Avenue is that way! INT. KATIE AND LAUREN’S APARTMENT - LAUREN’S ROOM - NIGHT Lauren, still in her pajamas is splayed across her bed wi pile of gossip rags. She listens to her iPod, but then casually pulls it out of her ears and stands up. She shoo to attention when she hears...

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (sexually) Mmmm. Oh yeah. That’s it. Lauren’s eyes go wide. KATIE (0.S.) (CONT’D) Fuck your nasty little slut! Ride me! Lauren doesn’t know if she should throw up or run. She gr her purse and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FANCY LOUNGE- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Lauren stares at Jesse, who sits across from her. He take big sip of his way too girly drink and sets it down.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You're not going to say anything?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Am I surprised she talks dirty when she’s getting some action? No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: No. That is not possible. I am fully qualified to work somewhere else and I will. This is a minor setback. But that girl, ooooh, I loathe her. She lies about everything. She doesn’t work in advertising. She. Hands. Out. Fliers! And you didn’t tell me!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Please don’t put me in the middle. She's great at handing out those fliers, she’s talkative and outgoing. Give her that, at least.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I am not giving that girl anything. I just hope I don’t have to meet whoever she’s sleeping with when he comes out of our bathroom and has inevitably peed on our floor, fondled my toothbrush and left small curly hairs by the sink. I’m sure he’s disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You're the one wearing pajama pants in a bar. INT. LAUREN’S BEDROOM- A LITTLE LATER Lauren enters the apartment, tentatively listening for Ka It is silent. With relief, she heads to her room, until--

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yess! Yess! Yessss! Beat that meat! Do it for ME! Lauren throws her purse down and charges to Katie’s door, then chickens out. Lauren crumples into her own room.

dialogues.text: I’m so close! Don’t let me down, baby. Oh GODDDDDDDDDDDDDD! INT. KATIE’S APARTMENT, KITCHEN - THE NEXT MORNING Katie hums “Eye of the Tiger” while pouring herself a bow Lucky Charms. Lauren enters, with rage in her eyes.  34.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Listen, whatever 12 hour porn shoot you were doing last night was ridiculous. We share a wall.

dialogues.text: I wasn’t shooting any porn. I was working all night long, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (a lightbulb goes off) Oh my god, you’re a prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Come on! Beat that meat!? Gross! If you want to have guys over, that’s fine, but just a little warning would be appreciated.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN

Once there’s a pile of very random foods on the counter, she digs in. She takes a bite of a peach, a spoo of peanut butter, a pickle.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Mmmm. You’re a good little peach. Bet you wouldn’t mind a little of this... Lauren tops her peach with some peanut butter and takes a bite. She sighs with pleasure. Just then, Katie’s voice i heard from inside her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (0.S.)

dialogues.text: (eyes bulging) Ohmygod.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (0.S.)

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: You got me soooo wet! THAT’S. WHAT. I’M. TALKING. ABOUT! !!! Lauren storms back to the door and POUNDS it with her fis Unexpectedly, it flies open! It reveals Katie, all alone the room, fully clothed, jumping up and down on her bed, the phone to her ear! Lauren is stunned. Katie’s face goes white. KATIE (INTO THE PHONE) (CONT’D) (quickly) Uh, just cum on my face. Gotta go. Katie looks at Lauren, wondering what she’s going to say. Lauren is silent.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your dad called? INT. KATIE AND LAUREN’S APARTMENT LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS L Lauren sits on the couch with her arms folded. Katie stud her from the pedicurists chair.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE LAUREN
dialogues.text: Listen, I’ve been doing-- Oh I know what you’ve been doing.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE LAUREN

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Ok. When I first got to New York, I had no money. I didn’t have a grand plan, like I’m sure you did, OK? (Lauren nods) I saw an ad for a dirty hotline and had a little phone interview and I got the job. I’m creative and am really good at knowing what guys want to hear, so I was great at it. I did it for a while and then stopped when my grandma died and I got her place with rent control. But then we moved in here, I needed to make more money for my half of the rent, so I got back into it. (sincerely) It's the only thing I’ve been good at since college. Obviously, I don’t really have a fancy advertising job. Lauren takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Ok, first off, get a landline. Are you retarded? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And listen, I think you should know if you’re really good at it, you’re wasting your time getting only 2 bucks a minute. You’re the one doing all the work and this stupid company is making 3 times as much as you for doing nothing. It’s actually offensive how short- sighted you are. Get your own hotline.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Ok, rude. I’ve thought of that. But I just don’t know how to even begin.

dialogues.text: Whatever. You’re just lazy. Call the phone company. Tell your clients. Done. (off Katie’s enlightened look) So...how do you know what to say?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Uhm, I just say what I normally say during sex. I know every button on aman and just when to push. When to cradle his- Lauren puts a hand up to get Katie to stop talking.

dialogues.text: Maybe I don’t really want to know.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: You must know some dirty words. Did you talk during sex with Charlie?

dialogues.text: Um... I would tell him he’s sexy.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: No, I wasn’t. I was mean. I really don’t think those things, okay?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Ok. I didn’t mean what I said either. Except you do really live in Candyland sometimes. But it’s ok! (notices the trench) Wait, what are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I just saw Charlie. And I thought maybe I’d show him how I grew over the summer, so... Lauren throws open her trench coat to reveal her sexy bra panties underneath.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: You went outside like this! You are so fucking cool. I have so much to tell you! I think I might try anal!

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Oh my!

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: You wanna move back in? I think we can still keep the place.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Please? Jesse is about 2 days away from kicking me to Long Island. He’s such a boy. The girls hug again. They make their way inside the build

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Thank god, because word must have gotten around about our 2-on-1’s and I’ve had to turn down so many. We should charge triple for those, don’t you think?  115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey, from the Amhearst luncheon sits in a leopard prin cubicle while on the phone. She reads from a Jane Austen novel.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: ‘It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.’ Now spank that meat, and pull my corset tight! My bosom heaves for you! Next to her cubicle is a zebra print cubicle in which Jes sits.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah, put it in my ass! He is beyond excited about this. Lauren and Katie walk past the cubicles. They give a thum up to Audrey and Jesse as they head to an office.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Who knew there was such a big market for those two? They enter the office and close the door. On the door is sign that says: “1-900-Mmm-Hmm.” FADE TO BLACK.
